Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 06:05AM ibcspouse wrote: Thought this article might be interesting to this discussion.  CancerConsultants.com - News 8/15/2008 Some women with early breast cancer remain at a substantial risk for developing a cancer recurrence years following therapy.Â These results were recently published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute. Early breast cancer refers to cancer that has not spread to distant sites in the body. Fortunately, following standard therapy for early breast cancer, cure rates remain high. However, a portion of patients with early breast cancer will experience a recurrence several years following therapy. Identification of factors associated with recurrences among these patients will allow for individualized therapeutic choices and/or stricter screening for recurrences. Researchers from the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center recently conducted a clinical study to explore the risks associated with recurrences several years following therapy for women with early breast cancer. The study included 2,838 patients with Stages I-III breast cancer who were treated with systemic (full-body) therapy between 1985 and 2001 and who had no sign of cancer five yearsÂ following the beginning of their therapy. At 10 years survival with no recurrences was achieved in 89% of patients, while at 15 years this rate was 80%. Five years following the completion of therapy, recurrence risks were 7% for patients with Stage I cancer; 11% for patients with St age II cancer; and 13% for patients with Stage III cancer. Patients with hormone-positive cancer (estrogen-receptor and/or progesterone-receptor positive) had an increased risk of a recurrence (13% at five years following completion of therapy) compared with those with hormone-negative cancers (7%); this difference was especially true for patients with hormone-positive breast cancer who did not receive endocrine (anti-estrogen) therapy. This study did not include measures of the human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) status or HerceptinÂ® (trastuzumab) and did not include patients treated with aromatase inhibitors, all of which may affect outcomes. The researchers concluded: â?oBreast cancer patients have a substantial residual risk of recurrence, and selected tumor characteristics are associated with late recurrences.â?� Overall, however, the risk of late recurrences remains low for patients with early breast cancer, and improved therapies may affect these outcomes. Nonetheless, it remains important to identify factors that may increase a patientâ?Ts risk for a recurrence so that therapy and monitoring may be individualized appropriately. Reference: Brewster A, Hortobagyi G, Broglio K, et al. Residual risk of breast cancer recurrence 5 years after adjuvant therapy. Journal of the National Cancer Institute [early online publication]. August 11, 2008. DOI: 10.1093/jnci/djn233.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 06:20AM ibcspouse wrote: Just a thought,  Avastin does not like hearts.  Taxol neither.  My wife's was put into congestive heart failure by avastin.  Chemo can and will damage the the left ventricle of heart, MD Anderson did study and said that combination of beta blockers and ace inhibitors after chemo can restore part or most of  damage.  Just getting off the chemo will show recovery, but treatment may be needed   Does your heart rate run higher than normal.  Please know that this is all personal experience with wife, and may have nothing to do with your symtoms.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 08:40PM ibcspouse wrote: KbatFishies First advise, get another oncologist.  The survival rate on IBC Stage 3b is much higher than 25%, Now, you are more likely than not to survive.  The goal on 3b is to cure it, not just treat.  The quote of 25 would make me believe that the onc is not up on latest info.  Also, with out PET scans, bone, brain, and CT, how does he stage it at 3b.  If that is the case, how does he know what treatment to use if it is not staged.  A lot of questions, a second opinion, or check ibcsupport.org for a lot more answers.  Good luck, the odds or in your mother's favor that she will be at the weddings and more.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2008 10:09AM ibcspouse wrote: Rosied51 Sorry you are going thru the worry and fear. You are doing the right thing by following up on that worry and researching on your own.  Yes, to you question, changes in nipple color is a symptom, my wife's changed to a whitish skin color, then inverted.  When she was dx, her supercavicle lymph nodes, was swollen and tested positive.  The dx of IBC is rare enough that the odds are in your favor that it is something else.  There are many things that will show these symptoms, but if the symptoms are present, make sure that the doctor's and surgeons follow correct protocol and completly rule out IBC.  That's their job, be an advocate for yourself and make them be willing to put in writting in your medical records, it is not IBC.  In a world of malpractice claims, this may make them go the extra mile is reaching a proper DX Good luck, I hope your visit to this site is only in passing and Breast Cancer is not a part of your life.
Posts.Title: Inflammatory breast cancer rosied51 rosied51

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2008 06:44PM ibcspouse wrote: Rosie, She had earlier symptoms, mainly pain and increase in size of breast first.  Her nipple changed colors on or about the time they started inverting and pinkish or purpleish tint to breast.  Read the "tell your stories on the IBC thread"  it will show that IBC can explode into symptoms or ladies who have problems for years before dx.  The supercavicle node increased in size early, before color change.  The axillary nodes toward armpits were the first to swell up.  Her chest wall was not invaded, she did have severe rash that developed after the color change.  This spread over top of both breast, up to her neck, and under arms.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 01:06AM ibcspouse wrote:  Since this is my wife's DR, I tend to believe in CTC, Cam's came down rapidly from 159 to O, the TM's were slower to come down, but came down to normal in a steady fashion.  They seemed to have a longer lag time.  Circulating Tumors Show Aggressive Disease Number of Cells May Determine Breast Cancer Treatment Patients with advanced breast cancer who have more than five circulating tumor cells in the blood may have a more dangerous form of the disease, according to an M. D. Anderson study. The pivotal study, published in the August issue of The New England Journal of Medicine, could lead to more tailored treatments that would spare some women from the most potent chemotherapy. It could also recognize which patients need more aggressive therapy at the start of treatment, says lead author Massimo Cristofanilli, M.D., associate professor in M. D. Anderson's Department of Breast Medical Oncology. "This is the first time that we can actually stratify metastatic breast cancer patients based on their risk," Cristofanilli says. "When a physician assesses a woman with metastatic breast cancer, it is very difficult to make an accurate prediction of her prognosis. Now we may know more about what the prognosis will be, based on a simple blood test and a new technology. One day we may be able to suggest to a patient - based on personal risk - a more aggressive treatment, a less aggressive treatment, or no treatment at all."

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2009 06:15PM ibcspouse wrote: At the International Conference on Inflammatory Breast Cancer, Dr. Lucci of MD Anderson gave his presentation saying there is almost no reason ever to have a excisional bx for IBC.  A punch bx is the recommended bx for IBC.  The change in dx of IBC is now to a pathological dx..must have tumor emboli in dermal lymphatic channels.  This is new and will result in fewer dx of IBC.  A MRI with proper wash out rates and instruction to Radiologist that looking for IBC is a good choice.  If your Dr says that "it is not IBC because of no masses"  be a good time to see another Dr.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 09:52PM ibcspouse wrote: bmdaley, My wife has been treated at MDA for the two years, for the last 10 months we live in sight of the the Mays Clinic, (the breast cancer clinic at MDA),  As far as getting to see them, it does not make a difference if you are self referred or Doc referred.  In either case, insurance info, med records and any bx slides need to be sent,  Copies of imagings such as xrays, mamms, mris, us or CT need to be carried.  Since it is 10 days to 2 weeks stay for the initial work up, be sure to check the list of places to stay that fits in the budget.  The Rotary House that is attached to MDA is a good place since it eliminates travel, security is not a problem, and you can rest between test, but it is a little pricey  .   Good luck

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2010 06:53AM ibcspouse wrote: Cheryl I am in the hospital now with Cam, my wife.  She came in with severe constipation, abdominal pain and a overall shortness of breath.  That was 4 days ago and are still here.  Many of the things you have is very similar to Cam.  She was dx with acute pancreatitis.  The pain she had and thought was gas pain, is described as a hard boring pain around and above navel that traveled thru to back.  She tried senna and mirolax but they only caused more gas and pain. The CT report "Extensive inflammatory changes about the pancreatic head with associated small bilateral pleural effusions and a small amount of ascites are consistent with pancreatitis, likely due to Xeloda therapy" They had a hard time dx this even with a prior CT scan on the first of Feb.  Her enzymes(amylase & Lipase) that "always are elevated with pancreatitis" were below normal, so dx was missed for a while.   Herbie The molassas enema they did in the ER worked wonders.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 11:13PM - edited Sep 18, 2008 11:15PM by ibcspouse The term Cell Search is the trade mark name for CTC testing by Veridex,LLC a Johnson and Johnson Co.        ABSTRACT Background We tested the hypothesis that the level of circulating tumor cells can predict survival in metastatic breast cancer. Methods In a prospective, multicenter study, we tested 177 patients with measurable metastatic breast cancer for levels of circulating tumor cells both before the patients were to start a new line of treatment and at the first follow-up visit. The progression of the disease or the response to treatment was determined with the use of standard imaging studies at the participating centers. Results Outcomes were assessed according to levels of circulating tumor cells at baseline, before the patients started a new treatment for metastatic disease. Patients in a training set with levels of circulating tumor cells equal to or higher than 5 per 7.5 ml of whole blood, as compared with the group with fewer than 5 circulating tumor cells per 7.5 ml, had a shorter median progression-free survival (2.7 months vs. 7.0 months, P<0.001) and shorter overall survival (10.1 months vs. >18 months, P<0.001). At the first follow-up visit after the initiation of therapy, this difference between the groups persisted (progression-free survival, 2.1 months vs. 7.0 months; P<0.001; overall survival, 8.2 months vs. >18 months; P<0.001), and the reduced proportion of patients (from 49 percent to 30 percent) in the group with an unfavorable prognosis suggested that there was a benefit from therapy. The multivariate Cox proportional-hazards regression showed that, of all the variables in the statistical model, the levels of circulating tumor cells at baseline and at the first follow-up visit were the most significant predictors of progression-free and overall survival. http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/short/351/8/781
